qas.question: When was "An Act for Liberty to Erect a Collegiate School" approved?
Who voted on "An Act for Liberty to Erect a Collegiate School"?

answers.text: General Court of the Colony of Connecticut

qas.question: What was the name of the group that started Yale's library?
Why was "An Act for Liberty to Erect a Collegiate School" proposed?

answers.text: to create an institution to train ministers and lay leadership for Connecticut

qas.question: Where did "The Founders" go to school?
When was "An Act for Liberty to Erect a Collegiate School" disapproved?

plausible_answers.text: General Court of the Colony of Connecticut

qas.question: Who never voted on "An Act for Liberty to Erect a Collegiate School"?
What was the name of the group that ended Yale's library?

plausible_answers.text: to create an institution to train ministers and lay leadership for Connecticut

qas.question: Why was "An Act for Liberty to Erect a Collegiate School" rejected?
Where didn't "The Founders" go to school?

context: Yale traces its beginnings to "An Act for Liberty to Erect a Collegiate School," passed by the <a1_0><b6_0>General Court of the Colony of Connecticut<b6_0/><a1_0/> on <a0_0><b5_0>October 9, 1701<b5_0/><a0_0/>, while meeting in New Haven. The Act was an effort <a3_0><b8_0>to create an institution to train ministers and lay leadership for Connecticut<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Soon thereafter, a group of ten Congregationalist ministers: Samuel Andrew, Thomas Buckingham, Israel Chauncy, Samuel Mather, Rev. James Noyes II (son of James Noyes), James Pierpont, Abraham Pierson, Noadiah Russell, Joseph Webb and Timothy Woodbridge, all alumni of <a4_0><b9_0>Harvard<b9_0/><a4_0/>, met in the study of Reverend Samuel Russell in Branford, Connecticut, to pool their books to form the school's library. The group, led by James Pierpont, is now known as "<a2_0><b7_0>The Founders<b7_0/><a2_0/>".[citation needed]
